text:
The protests in Colombia managed to bring about the 
withdrawal of a controversial tax reform
that already sounds like past history.

But now the demonstrations continue
throughout the country, in small and large cities,
and they look more and more violent and deadly.

Today we can say that the tax reform seems to have been
a trigger to resume

the protests that started on 21st November 
2019.

The “Paro Nacional” (National Strike), which was born that day, is
an unprecedented movement for Colombia.

It is heterogeneous and undoubtedly controversial 
because its alleged vandalism.

But if we try to summarize its main demands in 3 general lines
maybe we can understand it better,

and help explain why violence
has taken over the streets of Colombia.
First of all, protests seek a different police force.

Only in these past few days more
than 1,000 cases of police abuse have been documented

and authorities are investigating the disappearance of
dozens of people.

As seen in the streets, people say they are
tired
of police abusing their authority.
Not just in protests, but in everyday life.

Many Colombians feel that the public force
is not subject to disciplinary mechanisms
that are impartial, rigorous and efficient.

And that distrust in the public force,
especially among those who are protesting,

has a historical reason: Colombian police
is structured and trained to deal

with a context 
of an armed conflict against a common enemy: 
the Marxist guerrillas.

And from the point of view of citizens
who came out to protest, it is expected

that the force do not treat them as subversive citizens,
but as citizens who are making use of their democratic rights.

President Iván Duque took an important step
in this sense just a few weeks ago:

he decreed that the Military Criminal Justice be
a body independent of the military.
However, for his critics this was not enough.

They believe a comprehensive reform of the police 
that removes the force from that logic of conflict
is still overdue.

A second demand from the protests can be
summarized in the search
for a country at peace.

Duque came to power with the immense challenge
of implementing the peace agreement

with the FARC guerrillas, but his critics say
he, and especially his party,

have not only underfunded programs that protect
victims, but have also questioned

the court created to seek truth and justice over the armed conflict,
the so-called
Special Justice for Peace (Jurisdicción Especial para la Paz, JEP).

In addition, the opposition accuses Duque of using
the same old –and always questioned- strategies

for tackling problems: the spraying of coca crops, 
which he seeks to resume soon,

and the deployment of troops on the streets 
as during these protests.
Duque defends his policy for peace.

His main stake, which many experts
welcome, is the productive development
of the regions most affected by the conflict.

But for those who have taken to the streets
the lack of implementation of the peace agreements

has created a climate of violence in
the country.

And the result is evident every week with
an increase in massacres, murders of social leaders

and a mass displacement
population -yet again- in remote areas of the country.

So, in addition to a “post-conflict police”
Colombians expect a “post-conflict country”.

Because, -and this is a third demand-, there is a search for
a country that not only

overcomes the traumas of war, but also 
generates the mechanisms to end inequality and exclusion.

One of the most important criticisms of the tax reform
was that it placed a heavy weight on

the middle class, which is greatly affected by
the covid-19 pandemic.

But beyond the tax reform, the continuity
of the protests show that many people are fed up

with a conservative economic model that yes, it does 
give some macroeconomic stability to the country,

but at the same time it protects certain people and businesses 
and does not tackle inequality.

Duque is also seen as one of the main
executors of that economic model,

because he is a great ally of the private sector,
and he represents a party,

the Centro Democrático (Democratic Center),
that is very close to the landowner elite.
Several civil and political groups, as well as academics, who favor both

a
tax reform and protests, say that what is needed is a less patronage-based economy,

less dependant on cronyism, an economy that ends tax exemptions
for large companies
and opens the economy,
making it more democratic.
As I was saying, Colombia is a deeply unequal country.
It is the second most unequal in Latin America, after Brazil,

and the seventh
in the world, according to the World Bank.
This affects not only people´s finances, but also their access to services
in health and education.

So, a profound change in the economic model
that has been governing Colombia for more than a century
is at the heart of this movement of protest.

And if the people on the streets feel that
these problems are not being tackled,
it is difficult for the protests not to continue.

Hey, by the way, you guys have shown a
special interest in Colombia 
these days,

so in the comments tell us
what other issues you want us to address.
